Anansi and Vulture
 Ghanaian folktale
 English 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Anansi the Spider and Rabit were 
 
 friends. They lived in a peaceful vilage in 
 the mountains. 
 
 
 Rabit owned a big farm with lots of 
 vegetables and fruit. 
 
 
 Even though Rabit shared generously 
 with his friend, Anansi was unhapy and 
 
 jealous. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 1  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 So Anansi thought of a clever plan to
 take over Rabit’s farm. 
 
 
 Son Rabit was left por and homeles.
 Anansi was the proud owner of al
 
 Rabit’s land, vegetables, and fruit.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 2  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Anansi went to the market to sel his fruit 
 and vegetables. 
 
 
 He made so much money that he filed a 
 big basket with it! 
 
 
 With some of the money, he bought 
 
 maize for his family, and put it on top of 
 the money in the basket. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 3  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Anansi hapily headed home with his
 basket on his head, singing. 
 
 
 He was thinking about al the things he
 was going to buy with his money.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 4  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 On the way it started to drizle. 
 Son the drizle turned into a heavy 
 downpour. 
 
 
 Anansi the Spider left his basket on the 
 side of the road to shelter under a tre. 
 
 But from there he kept a close watch on 
 his precious basket. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 5  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 It started to rain even more heavily, and
 Anansi was geting cold and wet. So he
 ran into a hole. 
 
 
 “I wil stay in this hole until the rain
 stops,” said Anansi to himself. “At least
 
 my money is protected by the maize I put
 on top of it.” 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 6  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 A litle while later, Vulture was flying 
 around and spoted the basket on the 
 
 side of the road. 
 
 He saw that there was money and maize 
 
 in the basket. 
 
 
 So he covered the basket with his wings 
 and waited for the rain to stop. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 7  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Anansi saw Vulture siting on his basket.
 
 
 “Oh thank you, my friend, for protecting
 
 my basket,” he said to the Vulture.
 
 “Excuse me, Anansi, did I hear you right?”
 
 asked Vulture. “Your basket? This basket
 is mine! I found it here on the road side!”
 
 
 Anansi could not believe his ears! “It’s
 mine, I tel you!” 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 8  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Furious, Anansi went and reported the
 theft to the chief. But Vulture said to the
 
 chief and his elders, “How could anyone
 leave a basket ful of money and maize
 unguarded on the road?” 
 
 
 “But I was watching my basket,” said
 Anansi. “It’s my money and my maize!”
 
 
 “I was loking after the basket when you
 
 came and said it was yours!” replied
 Vulture. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 9  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 When the chief and his elders had
 
 listened carefuly to both sides, they sent
 Anansi and Vulture away. 
 
 
 They discused the story for a long time.
 
 
 Eventualy they reached a decision.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 10  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 They sumoned Anansi and the Vulture
 again. 
 
 
 “We believe Vulture’s story,” they said.
 “He is not the thief. You were trying to
 
 claim something that was not yours.”
 
 
 Anansi could not believe his ears! He
 burst into tears. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 1  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The news son spread that the 
 judgement had gone against Anansi.
 
 
 As he walked away, he heard Rabit
 laughing and laughing. 
 
 
 Rabit went back to his farm and grew
 fruit and vegetables. 
 
 
 But Anansi was por again, with no
 
 friends. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 12
